# Free Trade Area of the Americas

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas_logo.svg/200px-
Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas_logo.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas_logo.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas_logo.svg "Enlarge")

The Free Trade Area of the Americas logo

The **Free Trade Area of the Americas** (**FTAA** ; Spanish: _Área de Libre
Comercio de las Américas_ , ALCA; [French](/wiki/French_language "French
language"): _Zone de libre-échange des Amériques_ , ZLÉA;
[Portuguese](/wiki/Portuguese_language "Portuguese language"): _Área de Livre
Comércio das Américas_ , ALCA; [Dutch](/wiki/Dutch_language "Dutch language"):
_Vrijhandelszone van Amerika_) was a proposed agreement to eliminate or reduce
the [trade barriers](/wiki/Trade_barriers "Trade barriers") among all
countries in the [Americas](/wiki/Americas "Americas"), excluding
[Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba").

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

In the latest round of negotiations, trade ministers from 34 countries met in
[Miami](/wiki/Miami "Miami"), Florida, in the United States, in November 2003
to discuss the proposal.[1] The proposed agreement was an extension of the
[North American Free Trade
Agreement](/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement "North American Free
Trade Agreement") (NAFTA) between Canada, Mexico, and the United States.
Opposing the proposal were [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba"),
[Venezuela](/wiki/Venezuela "Venezuela"), [Bolivia](/wiki/Bolivia "Bolivia"),
[Ecuador](/wiki/Ecuador "Ecuador"), [Dominica](/wiki/Dominica "Dominica"), and
[Nicaragua](/wiki/Nicaragua "Nicaragua") (all of which entered the [Bolivarian
Alternative for the Americas](/wiki/Bolivarian_Alternative_for_the_Americas
"Bolivarian Alternative for the Americas") in response), and
[Mercosur](/wiki/Mercosur "Mercosur") member states. Discussions have faltered
over similar points as the [Doha Development
Round](/wiki/Doha_Development_Round "Doha Development Round") of [World Trade
Organization](/wiki/World_Trade_Organization "World Trade Organization") (WTO)
talks; developed nations seek expanded trade in
[services](/wiki/Service_Sector "Service Sector") and increased [intellectual
property](/wiki/Intellectual_property "Intellectual property") rights, while
less developed nations seek an end to [agricultural
subsidies](/wiki/Agricultural_subsidy "Agricultural subsidy") and free trade
in agricultural goods. Similar to the WTO talks, Brazil has taken a leadership
role among the less developed nations, while the United States has taken a
similar role for the developed nations.

###
Beginning[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Beginning")]

Free Trade Area of the Americas began with the [Summit of the
Americas](/wiki/Summit_of_the_Americas "Summit of the Americas") in Miami,
Florida, on December 11, 1994, but the FTAA came to public attention during
the [Quebec City Summit of the
Americas](/wiki/Quebec_City_Summit_of_the_Americas "Quebec City Summit of the
Americas"), held in Canada in 2001, a meeting targeted by massive [anti-
corporatization](/wiki/Anti-corporatization "Anti-corporatization") and [anti-
globalization](/wiki/Anti-globalization "Anti-globalization") protests. The
Miami negotiations in 2003 met similar protests, though perhaps not as large.

###
Disagreements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Disagreements")]

In previous negotiations, the United States had pushed for a single
comprehensive agreement to reduce trade barriers for goods, while increasing
intellectual property protection. Specific intellectual property protections
could include [Digital Millennium Copyright Act](/wiki/DMCA "DMCA")-style
copyright protections similar to the [U.S.-Australia Free Trade
Agreement](/wiki/U.S.-Australia_Free_Trade_Agreement "U.S.-Australia Free
Trade Agreement"). Another protection would likely restrict the reimportation
or cross-importation of pharmaceuticals, similar to the proposed agreement
between the United States and Canada. Brazil proposed a three-track approach
that calls for a series of bilateral agreements to reduce specific tariffs on
goods, a hemispheric pact on [rules of origin](/wiki/Rules_of_origin "Rules of
origin"), and a dispute resolution process; Brazil proposed to omit the more
controversial issues from the FTAA, leaving them to the WTO.

The location of the FTAA Secretariat was to have been determined in 2005. The
contending cities are: [Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta,_Georgia "Atlanta, Georgia"),
[Chicago](/wiki/Chicago "Chicago"), [Galveston](/wiki/Galveston,_Texas
"Galveston, Texas"), [Houston](/wiki/Houston,_Texas "Houston, Texas"), [San
Juan](/wiki/San_Juan,_Puerto_Rico "San Juan, Puerto Rico"), and
[Miami](/wiki/Miami "Miami") in the United States; [Cancún](/wiki/Canc%C3%BAn
"Cancún") and [Puebla](/wiki/Puebla,_Puebla "Puebla, Puebla") in Mexico;
[Panama City](/wiki/Panama_City "Panama City"), Panama; and [Port of
Spain](/wiki/Port_of_Spain "Port of Spain"), [Trinidad and
Tobago](/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago "Trinidad and Tobago"). The U.S. city of
[Colorado Springs](/wiki/Colorado_Springs,_Colorado "Colorado Springs,
Colorado") also submitted its candidacy in the early days but subsequently
withdrew.[2] Miami, Panama City and Puebla served successively as interim
secretariat headquarters during the negotiation process.

The last summit was held at [Mar del Plata](/wiki/Mar_del_Plata "Mar del
Plata"), Argentina, in November 2005, but no agreement on FTAA was reached. Of
the 34 countries present at the negotiations, 26 pledged to meet again in 2006
to resume negotiations, but no such meeting took place. The failure of the Mar
del Plata summit to establish a comprehensive FTAA agenda augured poorly.

### Current
status[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Current status")]

![Ambox current red.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Ambox_current_red.svg/42px-Ambox_current_red.svg.png) | This article needs to be **updated**. Please update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information. _(July 2016)_  
---|---  
  
The FTAA missed the targeted deadline of 2005, which followed the stalling of
useful negotiations of the [World Trade Organization Ministerial Conference of
2005](/wiki/World_Trade_Organization_Ministerial_Conference_of_2005 "World
Trade Organization Ministerial Conference of 2005").[3] Over the next few
years, some governments, most notably the United States, not wanting to lose
any chance of hemispheric trade expansion moved in the direction of
establishing a series of bilateral trade deals. The leaders however, planned
further discussions at the Sixth [Summit of the
Americas](/wiki/Summit_of_the_Americas "Summit of the Americas") in Cartagena,
Colombia, in 2012.[4][5]

## Support and
opposition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Support and opposition")]

A vocal critic of the FTAA was Venezuelan president [Hugo
Chávez](/wiki/Hugo_Ch%C3%A1vez "Hugo Chávez"), who has described it as an
"[annexation](/wiki/Annexation "Annexation") plan" and a "tool of
[imperialism](/wiki/Imperialism "Imperialism")" for the exploitation of Latin
America.[7] As a counterproposal to this initiative, Chávez promoted the
[Bolivarian Alliance for the
Americas](/wiki/Bolivarian_Alliance_for_the_Americas "Bolivarian Alliance for
the Americas") (_Alianza Bolivariana para las Américas_ , ALBA), based mostly
on the model of the [Eurasian Economic
Community](/wiki/Eurasian_Economic_Community "Eurasian Economic Community"),
which emphasizes energy and infrastructure agreements that are gradually
extended to other areas finally to include the total economic, political and
military integration of the member states.[7] [Evo Morales](/wiki/Evo_Morales
"Evo Morales") of Bolivia has referred to the U.S.-backed Free Trade Area of
the Americas, as "an agreement to legalize the colonization of the
Americas".[8]

On the other hand, the then presidents of Brazil, [Luiz Inácio Lula da
Silva](/wiki/Luiz_In%C3%A1cio_Lula_da_Silva "Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva"), and
Argentina, [Néstor Kirchner](/wiki/N%C3%A9stor_Kirchner "Néstor Kirchner"),
have stated that they do not oppose the FTAA but they do demand that the
agreement provide for the elimination of U.S. agriculture
[subsidies](/wiki/Subsidy "Subsidy"), the provision of effective access to
foreign markets and further consideration towards the needs and sensibilities
of its members.[9]

One of the most contentious issues of the treaty proposed by the United States
is with concerns to [patents](/wiki/Patent "Patent") and
[copyrights](/wiki/Copyright "Copyright"). Critics claim that if the measures
proposed by the United States were implemented and applied this would reduce
scientific research in Latin America. On the [left-wing](/wiki/Left-wing
"Left-wing") [Council of Canadians](/wiki/Council_of_Canadians "Council of
Canadians") web site, Barlow wrote: "This agreement sets enforceable global
rules on patents, copyrights and trademark. It has gone far beyond its initial
scope of protecting original inventions or cultural products and now permits
the practice of patenting plants and animal forms as well as seeds. It
promotes the private rights of corporations over local communities and their
genetic heritage and traditional medicines".[10]

On the weekend of April 20, 2001, the [3rd Summit of the
Americas](/wiki/3rd_Summit_of_the_Americas "3rd Summit of the Americas") was a
[summit](/wiki/Summit_\(meeting\) "Summit \(meeting\)") held in [Quebec
City](/wiki/Quebec_City "Quebec City"), Canada. This international meeting was
a round of negotiations regarding a proposed FTAA.

##
Agreements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Agreements")]

There are currently 34 countries in the Western Hemisphere, stretching from
Canada to Chile that still have the FTAA as a long term goal.[11] The
Implementation of a full multilateral FTAA between all parties could be made
possible by enlargement of existing agreements. North America, with the
exception of Cuba and Haiti (which has participated in economic integration
with the [Caricom](/wiki/Caricom "Caricom") since 2002)[12][13] has come close
to setting up a subcontinental free trade area. At this point Agreements
within the Area of the Americas include:

### Previous
agreements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Previous agreements")]

  * Canada: [Canada–United States Free Trade Agreement](/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_Free_Trade_Agreement "Canada–United States Free Trade Agreement") (1988; superseded by the NAFTA)
  * Costa Rica- Dominican Republic (superseded by [DR-CAFTA](/wiki/DR-CAFTA "DR-CAFTA"))
  * Costa Rica- Trinidad and Tobago (superseded by a Costa Rica - [CARICOM](/wiki/CARICOM "CARICOM") FTA).

### Current
agreements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Current agreements")]

  * Canada, Mexico and United States: [North American Free Trade Agreement](/wiki/North_American_Free_Trade_Agreement "North American Free Trade Agreement") (NAFTA; 1994)
  * Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Nicaragua, Dominican Republic and United States: [Dominican Republic–Central America Free Trade Agreement](/wiki/Dominican_Republic%E2%80%93Central_America_Free_Trade_Agreement "Dominican Republic–Central America Free Trade Agreement") (DR-CAFTA; 2008)
  * Chile, Colombia, Mexico and Peru: [Pacific Alliance](/wiki/Pacific_Alliance "Pacific Alliance") (2012)
  * [Chile–United States Free Trade Agreement](/wiki/Chile%E2%80%93United_States_Free_Trade_Agreement "Chile–United States Free Trade Agreement") (2004)
  * [Peru–United States Trade Promotion Agreement](/wiki/Peru%E2%80%93United_States_Trade_Promotion_Agreement "Peru–United States Trade Promotion Agreement") (2007)
  * [United States–Colombia Free Trade Agreement](/wiki/United_States%E2%80%93Colombia_Free_Trade_Agreement "United States–Colombia Free Trade Agreement") (2011)
  * [Panama–United States Trade Promotion Agreement](/wiki/Panama%E2%80%93United_States_Trade_Promotion_Agreement "Panama–United States Trade Promotion Agreement") (2011)
  * Bolivia - Mexico
  * Canada - Chile
  * Canada - Colombia
  * Canada - Costa Rica
  * Canada - Honduras
  * Canada - Panama
  * Canada - Peru
  * Chile - Mexico
  * Chile - Costa Rica
  * Costa Rica - Mexico
  * Costa Rica - CARICOM
  * Mexico - Nicaragua
  * Mexico - Uruguay
  * Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay and Venezuela - [Mercosur](/wiki/Mercosur "Mercosur") (1991)
  * Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru - [Andean Community](/wiki/Andean_Community "Andean Community") (1969)

### Proposed
agreements[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Free_Trade_Area_of_the_Americas&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Proposed agreements")]

Active negotiations

  * Canada-CARICOM:[14]
  * Canada-Central America (CA4TA - Guatemala, El Salvador, Nicaragua, Honduras)[15]
  * Canada-Mexico-Peru-Chile [among other Pacific nations]: [Trans-Pacific Partnership](/wiki/Trans-Pacific_Partnership "Trans-Pacific Partnership")

Negotiations on hold

  * CARICOM-[Mercosur](/wiki/Mercosur "Mercosur"):[16]
  * United States-Ecuador: [U.S.-Ecuador Free Trade Agreement](/w/index.php?title=US-Ecuador_Free_Trade_Agreement&action=edit&redlink=1 "US-Ecuador Free Trade Agreement \(page does not exist\)")
  * CARICOM-North American Free Trade Agreement, first discussed in 1993–1994[17]
